results.title: Equality. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Art Ciocco, Paul Buck, Ken Stein, Best Films and New Jersey Public Television
results.brief_description: Explores the diversity of people and the breadth of the problems as one searches for “equality”. Concentrates on the basic areas of economics, ethnic groups, problems of old age and alternate lifestyle. Contains some b&w sequences.

results.title: The Conductor. Pt. 2
results.creator_credit: Milton Ingerson, Malcolm Smith and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A look at the art and technique of the conductor. In part two, conductor Verdon Williams discusses the tasks that a conductor must do before each performance - choosing the number and type of instruments needed; studying the melody and style of the music. Shows him rehearsing an orchestra and a choir.

results.title: The Photographer
results.creator_credit: Willard Van Dyke and Affiliated Film Producers
results.brief_description: The life and work of the American photographer, Edward Weston. The artist is shown at work in California; shows the manner in which Mr Weston approaches his selection of material for pictorial composition and techniques he uses for developing the print. The film includes glimpses of the home of the artist and studies of the sea and mountain landscape of California. Commentary by Irving Jacoby. Narrated by Mel Brandt.

results.title: One hundred harvests
results.creator_credit: Robert Hesselschwerdt and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: A historical review of the work done on cereal breeding since the establishment of the Department of Agriculture in 1872. Includes shots of many old farming implements housed in the Historical Museum of Jeparit. Shows stages in the development of new varieties of wheat at Werribee Research Farm. Made in connection with centenary of the Department.

results.title: Quayside
results.brief_description: The Quayside was the old commercial area in Newcastle. It is now under threat from the redeveloper’s hammer. The film is a poetic lament about its past while indicating fears for its future. Elaborate tracking devices were used in making the film and a soundtrack constructed from files found in old shipping offices.

results.title: Protist behaviour (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Shows avoidance reactions, mechanisms for aggregation in favorable environemtns, predator-prey relationships, light reactions, and escape responses in free-living protists.

results.title: The Pill = Pilula = La Pilule = Die Tablette
results.brief_description: When a pill is dropped in a glass of water, it produces froth which overflows the glass, invades the room, the apartment, the street, the city and ends up covering the whole world.

results.title: Paul Klee: child of creation (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Ed Leimbacher, Joe Valentine, Paul Taylor and King Screen Productions
results.brief_description: With a colourful flow of images, this film directly relates the work of the famous 20th century painter, Paul Klee, to the artistic creations of young children. Klee’s own words are complemented by youngsters’ candid comments to reveal an unmistakable kinship between master and young beginner. A delightful portrait of Paul Klee for all levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ed Leimbacher, Joe Valentine, Paul Taylor and King Screen Productions

results.title: Getting started
results.creator_credit: Richard Condie, Jerry Krepakevich, Michael Scott and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In this animated film the hero attempts to practise a piece of music on the piano. A series of distractions delays him and, when he finally sits down to play, pandemonium breaks loose. A short film that will appeal to those of us who tend to procrastinate. (Awards include: Toronto, Zagreb)

results.title: T.E. Lawrence
results.creator_credit: Malcolm Brown, Philip Donnellan and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: Portrait of “Lawrence of Arabia” a profoundly controversial figure with a reputation swinging between hero worship on the one hand and contempt on the other. Tells the story of his life and death (1935) with the richest and most authentic material available in the hope that a real and credible Lawrence will emerge. Original photographs, drawings of Eric Kennington, and mementos from friends are used. Written and narrated by David Lytton, voice of T.E. Lawrence by Cyril Cusack.
